text: 4Q24 Financial Results
4Q24 and FY24 Financial Results start on page 1.
Financial Outlook starts on page 9.
Notes start on page 12.
Return on tangible common equity (ROTCE) was 21%.
CET1 capital ratios were 15.7% (Standardized) and 15.8% (Advanced).
Total Loss-Absorbing Capacity was $547B.
Standardized Risk-Weighted Assets (RWA) were $1.8T.
Cash and marketable securities stood at $1.4T.
Average loans were $1.3T.
4Q24 net income was $14.0B and EPS was $4.81.
Managed revenue was $43.7B.
Expense was $22.8B and the managed overhead ratio was 52%.
Average loans of $1.3T were up 2% YoY and 1% QoQ.
Average deposits of $2.4T were up 2% YoY and 1% QoQ.
CET1 capital was $276B.
Common dividend was $3.5B or $1.25 per share.
Common stock net repurchases amounted to $4.0B.
Net payout for the last twelve months (LTM) was 54%.
Net income of $4.5B was down 6% YoY.
Revenue of $18.4B was up 1% YoY, driven by higher noninterest revenue in Card Services & Auto and Home Lending, partially offset by lower net interest income.
Expense of $9.7B was up 4% YoY, driven by higher compensation for advisors and bankers, and higher technology expense.
Credit costs were $2.6B.
Net charge-offs (NCOs) of $2.1B were up $428mm YoY, driven by Card Services due to seasoning of recent vintages and balance growth.
Net reserve build of $557mm was predominantly in Card Services, driven by growth in revolving balances.
Average loans were up 1% YoY and QoQ.
Average deposits were down 4% YoY and flat QoQ.
End-of-period (EOP) deposits were down 3% YoY and flat QoQ.
Active mobile customers were up 7% YoY.
Debit & credit card sales volume was up 8% YoY.
Client investment assets were up 14% YoY and 2% QoQ.
Net income of $6.6B was up 59% YoY; revenue of $17.6B was up 18% YoY.
IB revenue of $2.6B was up 46% YoY, driven by higher fees across all products.
Payments revenue of $4.7B was up 6% YoY.
Excluding the net impact of equity investments, Payments revenue was up 3%, driven by higher deposit balances and fee growth, offset by deposit margin compression.
Lending revenue of $1.9B was up 9% YoY, driven by lower losses on hedges of the retained lending portfolio.
Markets revenue of $7.0B was up 21% YoY.
Fixed Income Markets revenue of $5.0B was up 20% YoY, driven by higher revenue in Credit and Currencies & Emerging Markets.
Equity Markets revenue of $2.0B was up 22% YoY, driven by higher client activity in Derivatives and Cash.
Securities Services revenue of $1.3B was up 10% YoY, driven by fee growth, higher client activity, and higher deposit balances.
Expense of $8.7B was up 7% YoY, driven by higher brokerage, technology, and legal expense.
Credit costs were $61mm, driven by net downgrade activity and charge-offs, largely offset by a reserve release.
Net charge-offs (NCOs) were $300mm and there was a net reserve release of $239mm.
Net income of $1.5B was up 25% YoY.
Revenue of $5.8B was up 13% YoY, driven by growth in management fees, strong net inflows, and higher performance fees.
Expense of $3.8B was up 11% YoY, driven by higher compensation and distribution fees.
AUM of $4.0T and client assets of $5.9T were each up 18% YoY, driven by continued net inflows and higher market levels.
For the quarter, AUM had long-term net inflows of $76B and liquidity net inflows of $94B.
Average loans of $234B were up 3% YoY and 2% QoQ.
Average deposits of $249B were up 10% YoY and 5% QoQ.
Revenue of $2.0B was up $223mm YoY.
Net interest income of $2.0B was down $415mm YoY, driven by lower rates, largely offset by securities reinvestment.
Noninterest revenue was a net loss of $30mm, an improvement from a net loss of $668mm in the prior year, driven by lower net investment securities losses.
Expense of $550mm was down $3.0B YoY, predominantly driven by the absence of the $2.9B FDIC special assessment in the prior year.
The outlook for 2025 NII ex. Markets is ~$90B.
The outlook is based on an implied rate curve with one rate cut, with the Federal Funds target upper bound at 4.25% at year-end.
Balance sheet growth, including card revolve growth and higher deposit balances, is expected to partially offset lower rates.
The 2025 outlook for Markets NII is ~$4B, leading to a Firmwide NII outlook of ~$94B.
Volume and revenue-related expenses are expected to be driven by auto lease growth and capital markets activity.
Continued investment is planned for Bankers, Advisors, Branches, and International Consumer Initiatives to foster business growth.
Technology expenses will be driven by business growth, investments, public cloud, data centers, and cyber security.
Marketing spend will continue to drive demand for card products and customer engagement.
Inflation is expected to contribute ~$2B to expense growth across the firm.
Expect FY2025 net interest income of ~$94B, market dependent.
Expect FY2025 net interest income excluding Markets of ~$90B, market dependent.
Expect FY2025 adjusted expense of ~$95B, market dependent, which excludes Firmwide legal expense.
Expect FY2025 Card Services NCO rate of ~3.6%.
The Firm reviews results on a 'managed' basis, a non-GAAP measure, to present revenue on a fully taxable-equivalent basis for comparability.
Metrics excluding Markets, such as NII and NIR, are non-GAAP measures used to assess performance of core lending, investing, and deposit-raising activities separately from Markets volatility.
Tangible common equity (TCE), return on tangible common equity (ROTCE), and tangible book value per share (TBVPS) are non-GAAP measures used to assess the Firm's use of equity.
Full-year 2024 results included significant items: a $7.9B net gain on Visa shares, a $1.0B donation, $546mm in net investment securities losses, and a $725mm increase to the FDIC special assessment.
Adjusted expense and adjusted overhead ratio are non-GAAP measures that exclude Firmwide legal expenses to provide an alternate view of performance.
CET1 capital and Total Loss-Absorbing Capacity as of December 31, 2024, reflected the remaining $720mm CECL capital transition benefit.
Total excess high-quality liquid assets (HQLA) represents the average eligible unencumbered liquid assets in excess of what is required under the LCR rule.
During the fourth quarter of 2024, a change in funds transfer pricing for consumer deposits increased the funding benefit in CCB, with a full offset in Corporate net interest income.
For Consumer & Community Banking (Slide 5), active mobile customers are defined as users who have logged in within the past 90 days.
Firmwide mortgage origination volume was $14.2B in 4Q24, compared to $13.3B in 3Q24 and $8.6B in 4Q23.
For Commercial & Investment Bank (Slide 6), the segment was formed in 2Q24 by combining the former Corporate & Investment Bank and Commercial Banking segments.
In 4Q24, certain net funding costs previously allocated to Fixed Income Markets were reclassified to Equity Markets.
The presentation contains forward-looking statements based on current beliefs and expectations, which are subject to significant risks and uncertainties.
Actual results may differ materially from those set forth in the forward-looking statements.
Factors causing potential differences are described in the company's SEC filings.
JPMorgan Chase & Co. does not undertake to update any forward-looking statements.
